instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.U5000: What is U5000? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in macbooks from 2013-2015.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC: What is PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC? PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC Is a reference voltage for the SMCâ€™s voltage sensors & other sensors..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Have this board that  came in with some corrosion damage and wasn't powering. Clean up the corrosion and replaced any corroded components, but still not powering up. What i get is two pulses on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>, and even <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> at initial point of connecting the MagSafe. 

No activity on smc bypass.

<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> 3.4V
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> 3.4V

Attempted triggering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> while checking <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> doesn't change. Remains at 3.4v. 

Any suggestions

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Check all SPI Bus Series Termination resistors and their traces.
Clean/remove J6100, if needed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
All SPI bus resistors and traces good. 
No change after removing J6100

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Do you get steady <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?

Check for correct oscillation at Y5110.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message: no clock oscillation at Y5110 just DC voltage at pin 1 @ about 1.5v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message: what could cause <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> not to respond when <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is triggered? I've replaced the SMC with the same result.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
SMC controls <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>, but it can be blocked by PCH.
1.5V DC could be good at Y5110, but is better to confirm with o-scope in this case.
At least compare with similar good board DC level on both pins of Y5110.

Check power and signals for <CHIP>U5000</CHIP> (2 OF 2) at page 38.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
o-scope only showing DC signal. On a good board, it's about 1.35v.

<CHIP>U5000</CHIP> measurement:
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S5_SMC_VDDC</SIGNAL> - 1.2v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> - 3.3
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SMC</SIGNAL> - 3.4
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 3.38
<SIGNAL>SMC_WAKE_L</SIGNAL> - 2.9
<SIGNAL>SMC_CLK32K</SIGNAL> - 32.77k

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Y5110 should have 12MHz oscillation.
If not, check its components and traces.
You may need to change SMC.
